nodes.text: Conservation of money in agent transactions and statistical physics methods can explain observed money and income distributions and illuminate monetary instability mechanisms
In monetary transactions among ordinary agents money is locally conserved (transferred but not created by agents), a law of accounting analogous to conservation laws in physics
Use kinetic theory: model money distribution P(m,t) with a Boltzmann-type kinetic equation for pairwise transfers and reduce to a Fokker-Planck equation for small transfers
If microscopic transaction dynamics satisfy time-reversal symmetry (detailed balance), the stationary money distribution is exponential P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm)
For additive processes (constant drift and diffusion coefficients) the Fokker-Planck stationary solution is exponential with money temperature Tm = B/A
Maximum entropy principle under fixed total money yields the exponential distribution as the most probable macrostate and entropy increases monotonically toward it
Agent-based simulations starting from equal balances and with boundary m>0 evolve to the stationary exponential distribution, demonstrating instability of perfect equality
Empirical income data (IRS, US) show a two-class structure: lower-class incomes follow exponential distribution, upper-class incomes follow a Pareto power law
Economy has two distinct layers: a physical layer (goods and services, not conserved) and a monetary layer (digital money, conserved within agent system); money and wealth are different concepts
Debt is a promissory third layer distinct from money; debt creation produces paired positive and negative claims, removes the lower-boundary constraint, and allows negative net worth
If debt is unrestricted, net-worth distribution broadens without reaching equilibrium and entropy can increase without bound; interest exacerbates divergence rather than stabilizing it

Commercial banks do not create exogenous money but create corresponding debt/liabilities by issuing loans (analogy to particle-antiparticle creation); reserve requirements are a soft constraint and often do not cap debt creation in practice
Central bank (state) can inject exogenous money by monetizing government debt or buying assets; such injections convert privately created debt into state-created money

Empirical evidence (IRS time series, Fig.1) shows spikes in upper-class income share associated with market bubbles and Quantitative Easing, indicating central bank actions and bailouts increase income inequality

Because exogenous state money created during bailouts provides the net new money that can fund aggregate interest and capitalist profit, the ultimate source of broad monetary profit is state money (monetization of debt)

Limitation/assumption: the theoretical results rely on assumed conservation, choice of transaction rules (additive vs multiplicative) and time-reversal symmetry; appropriateness of these assumptions for real economies is debated
